I knew I'd find a few things to get annoyed with right away, but this is a PC port of a CAVE game that runs fine at first glance and offers all the content available in the 360 versions. Such a thing was a pipe dream for a long time but here we go, Mushihimesama on Steam. What a big day. Buy this game immediately if you've never played Mushihimesama. You've been missing out for years and so have I. On to some ratings and complaints:

10/10 Original game
9/10 Supplementary content
9/10 Port job
7/10 Conversion for PC audience
9.5/10 Post-release support


Sound/music for some modes pretty lofi quality. They've worked on some of that (1.5) post-release, this is of course an old arcade came from a board with terrible sound to begin with. Fixing/arranging more of the music would definitely make it a better arcade conversion to the home audience.

Could use an FPS counter.
I'd like to have an option to get rid of the xbox360 button graphics in menu dialogs etc.
Would be nice if the CAVE bootscreen and 1st title screen were shown in a vertical orientation in TATE mode.

The screen zoom settings are applied per mode rather than globally which may require you to set this up 4 times in a row the first time you play the game, but on the other hand, this lets you set different wallpapers for each mode, which some players might like a lot, so I think changing this on the setup side, you'd still want to let people change some things per mode. It's not really a big deal.

Obviously I'd love to see a new Arrange mode as DLC in the future but I'm sure they will be too busy priming more old games for release in general to take such a long look back into the game code. I'd love to see an Arrange from any of the CAVE devs who didn't work on the original game, but I'd love to see what some random hacker did with it too. Pipe dreams, again.

This is an absolute must buy for any STG fan who hasn't been fortunate enough to import Japanese region-locked games. Thank you so much Blackbird and Degica for this.

If you have any problems with the game please contact Degica support and I'm sure they will get most of it sorted out. This is certainly worlds better than any DotEmu wrapped emulator rerelease and Degica have rapidly become a godsend to bullet chasers worldwide. This will almost certainly become the definitive version of Mushihimesama.

Please excuse any errors on my part as I'm just now playing the game and I have never played the original port or arcade board.

reviewText:
Mushihimesama is a vertical Bullet Hell in where you play as a girl riding a giant beetle and shooting other giant bugs into oblivion. The reason why is explained at the end of the game but even then you will be left confused as to what happened and be left feeling like you just walked in to the ending of a movie with no context as to what it was about. Very few people go into a bullet hell expecting a engrossing story though I found it funny to be greeted with what was supposed to be a tear-jerking ending when the game didn't even so much as tell me the main character's name before that scene. It may sound weird to start off a review talking about the ending but this is a very short game and you will âbeat itâ in about half an hour or less, regardless of your skill level. This game features unlimited continues so everyone will be able to get through it if they are persistent enough. However the feature allowing you to save a replay of your play-through will cut off at the point you first lost all lives and had to use a continue.

There are three modes to play here, them being Novice, Normal and Arrange. Novice is exactly what it sounds like and makes the game considerably easier by having less projectiles and simpler bullet curtains compared to Normal mode. This is definitely the mode to start with if you are new or out of practice to the genre. Arrange is a remix of the game that tweaks with certain aspects of the game that I will cover more thoroughly in a bit. Each mode minus Arrange has both score attack in which you compete with your friends and âplayâ. While in either mode you will have the option of either picking âOriginalâ, âManiacâ for higher scores as well as more challenge and finally âUltraâ, for when you want to throw your controller/keyboard across the room in utter frustration at the real last boss wiping the floor with you. You will also be able to change the amount of lives you have and at what score you get more. Finally you will be able to pick which one of the three bullet formations you want to have, S-Power for a stream of condensed bullets for heavy damage, W-Power for a screen filling low damage attack and M-Power that is a mix of both. There are quite a bit of options for you to mess around with to say the least.

Now that you are finally in the game and shooting bugs you will notice that this is pretty much what you would expect from a bullet hell. Bombs to clear the screen of projectiles, a counter to keep track of your score and a ton of enemies wanting nothing more than to shoot you out of the air. It does all of this very well and keeps you in a trance like state as you splatter all the bugs and collect all the yellow gems they drop to rake in a high score. Black enemy beetles carry power-ups so you will want to shoot these buggers down. The power-ups are either a small ally beetle that will shoot beams whenever you press the fire button, an upgrade to your projectiles or if you are about to fight a boss, a couple of bombs. A neat thing about the upgrade projectile power-up is that you can let its timer count down and it will change into a different type of shot. So say that you are shooting condensed projectiles but this part of the level is filled with a ton of enemies, simply wait for the power-up to change into a wide-shot formation and you will now have a much more suitable, screen filling projectile attack. This is a really neat system that makes it beneficial to learning the three projectile types instead of always sticking with what you know.

Enemies in this game are huge and their size does matter as they will fire larger projectiles the bigger they are. That's not to say you shouldn't be cautious of the smaller enemies as well, since they fire tiny projectiles it can be easy for them to shoot you when you are focusing on a gigantic enemy. Remember that you are flying, you will be able to pass over some ground enemies when the amount of projectiles get intense and it seems there is nowhere to go. Projectiles are bright purple and very easy to spot, so if you get hit it will always feel like your fault. All of the five stages have a mid-boss that you will have to face and will leave if you take too much time with them. Bosses are where you will be most tempted to use your bombs as they will shower you with intricate bullet patterns. These moments are when you will most likely experience slowdown that will bring the action down to a crawl. The developers have stated that these are on purpose to give you a chance to react to all that is happening on screen though it would be nice to have an option to toggle the slow down on or off nonetheless.

That finally brings us to Arrange mode. This is only a mode you'd want to play if you are already familiar with the game, it only has the ultra difficulty meaning the game is at its most brutal and you will have to face the aforementioned real last boss. She is the most shump/bullet hell boss I have ever encountered by far. It is an extremely difficult fight and to top it off she has an absurd amount of health. It will takes longer to whittle down her health and defeat her than it does to play through most of the game. Now with that out of the way onto what makes Arrange mode different from the other two modes. For one you start the game fully powered up and are able to kill the earlier enemies much easier than usual.  You will also have a feature most other games call âauto-bombâ which causes your character to automatically toss a bomb, clearing the screen when you are about to get hit. In this case she will throw all your bombs if you get hit, making your rate of survival much lower so you will not want to rely on that feature over your instinct of when to use them. The final thing that makes this mode much different is the ability to change your form of projectiles on the whim, to any of the three types available.

Music in this game is a calm and soothing strangely enough. Stranger still is that it somehow fits in with the whole shooting giant bugs theme of the game. That is mostly due to the nice environments that range from flying over the water, across deserts and through giant trees. You will also be able to mix and match the music to play stages with either of the two soundtracks available. If you are playing this game horizontally you will be able to pick from 12 backgrounds to cover the parts of the screen that goes unused. Vertically is how this game was meant to be played, so if you have a monitor that can pivot that would be the ideal way to play this, though you can't go wrong either way. Annoyingly enough you will have to tweak the screen settings and the background in each of the three modes separately. One global setting would have been much preferred instead of having to tweak the game to our liking in all three modes. At the end of the day however, that is a minor complaint that will hopefully be fixed in a patch. This is a blast to play and due to its length won't take up much of your time in your attempts to master the game. Mushihimesama is an excellent bullet hell with plenty of content to keep you coming back and is hopefully the first in many of developer Cave's games to be released on the PC.

I won't write a review for the game itself, you can already find countless of them on steam and over the internet. I'll just review the port. I've waited for some time and observed how things were going before either bashing or praising the port. After 2 months, much has happened, things are more or less settled so I think it's the right moment.

At release, let's be honest, game was in a clumsy state: crash problems, leaderboards problems, rendering problems and what not. It was far from the Batman disaster hopefully, but it could definitely have been better. Since it was CAVE first PC release, I think it would have been wiser from them to do like SNKP with KoF XIII and let users pre-purchase the game in beta so they could benefit from their feedback and bug reports. Which is more or less what happened here, except it is not what we expected, and thus, not paid for.

But we can't go back in time so let's look forward instead : since the 6th november (so in less than 2 months when I write this review), they have released no less than 6 patches, most issues have been addressed and they still listen to players for the few issues remaining. They work hard, and fast. They acknowledge their mistakes and do their best to fix them.

I wouldn't have recommended Mushihimesama at its release. Frankly. But now, there's no reason to keep your wallet closed for this game. CAVE devs proved that they are concerned and dedicated to the quality of their ports. They have proved it was more than a mere cash grab. Now we can wait for their future releases with an optimistic state of mind.

This port is Dark Souls quality. That this is based on the Xbox 360 version is apparent with all the same menus and such. What makes it even more apparent are the little amenities made for the PC and the introduced issues:

-The game is locked to horizontal 720p.
-This means vertical mode (TATE) must be used in a horizontal resolution.
-Movement is hard-bound to the arrow keys. (This will be addressed in an upcoming patch)
-Keybindings are thankfully available, however, half of my keyboard doesn't seem to be recognized.
-There are crashes upon pressing Start at the title screen, entering/exiting a game mode, and quitting the game. (Pressing Alt+Tab or waiting a few beats before doing the action might help you, but there are some gamers who can't get around these crashes at all. This will be addressed in an upcoming patch too.)
-I'm not sure if it's just me, but sometimes I find Reco continue moving in a direction a split second after I stopped pressing into that direction.
-Sometimes, the main menu items disappear upon returning from a game mode.

To fix some of these issues, particularly the crashes and locked resolution and even frame rate ones, look up GeDoSaTo and set it up.

Past these flaws, the game itself seems to run beautifully. The new HD visuals are more pleasing on the eyes compared to their blurry arcade originals. I can't comment on the accuracy of slowdown compared to the Xbox 360 version or the arcade PCB, but Degica did get members of the shmup community who own either versions to playtest.

If you're new to shmups, then this game might seem too overpriced for what seems like a quick half-hour affair, but that's ignoring the brilliance of arcade gameplay that truly shines when you aim to complete the game in only one credit (1CC, one credit clear) without any continues. Probably the best analogy for this post-arcade and post-NES age is speedrunning. As you play through the stages over and learn from your mistakes, you start learning the stages and developing all sorts of strategies and techniques to carry you over to the final goal of surviving the entire game. That alone will give you hours upon hours of gameplay. If you enjoy the game and want even more hours of gameplay, then you can kick up the difficulty and this game offers in addition to Original, Maniac and Ultra. Or you can start getting into scoring and aim for the global high scores. Or you can check out the other modes that come with this game.

The new modes give a great shakeup with Arrange being a full-powered big numbers scoring affair (with autobombs) and 1.5 injecting more excitement into the base game with a stronger shot, more pronounced slowdowns, and an emphasis on point-blanking along with some tweaking to the stages. Personally, 1.5 is a must-have and it really makes this port so grab that too.

While Mushihimesama isn't my favorite Cave game, I could see why this would be their first released title. This game (Xbox 360 version) never got a region-free release. It also has an emphasis on styilized slowdowns as if you're dodging in bullet time, which is a nice introduction for newcomers to the bullet hell genre. Another newbie-friendly mechanic is the consistent use of bullet-canceling. Throughout the stages, there are huge enemies that spit out massive bullet patterns and if they are defeated, then all the bullets on the screen disappear into gems, giving you a breather and encouraging you to gather as many bullets as possible. There is also a focus on the basic manuvering skill of going from one side of the screen to another as opposed to the more complex approaches of other Cave games.

The scoring mechanics are also fairly simple too. Original focuses on doing chip damage, destruction of boss parts, and surviving. Maniac/Ultra are about boosting up the multiplier by controlling your shot rate against certain enemies from certain positions on the screen to milk them for points before destroying them, and then chaining from one enemy to another to maintain the multiplier and prevent it from decreasing. Arrange/1.5 modes introduce point-blanking for gems. On top of all this are other minor mechanics such as the aforementioned bullet-canceling or no-missing" (never dying within a stage for bonus points). Personally

reviewText:
Mushihimesama is a brilliant CAVE shooter that is a direct port of the 360 version, available for people on PC for the first time. Mushihimesama sets a standard in terms of modern STGs and cave games in general that we can get a taste for and is absolutely worth your time.

GameplayVertical shooter, you control 1 ship called Reco and you have a choice of 3 different shot types they are :
M-Power (best all round shot type)
W-Power (wide shot type for clearing large groups of enemies in stages, low mobility)
S-Power (powerful concentrated attack good for taking out bosses and single targets, fastest)
In game certain enemies drop the icon which gives you the power ups, there is a timer that counts down if you don't collect the power up within the time it switches to a different shot type which could be good if you need it for a specific boss enemy,or you are looking to clear specific enemies meaning it helps you plan more strategic.
There are 3 bombs given to you at the start but not like the classic screen clear bombs you get given a bomb that affects a certain area, you are still invincible during its active frames but you have to aim where you want it to go.It is also used in advanced techniques such as misdirection allowing you to have a better chance of surviving challenging patterns.
You start with 2 lives, and the first 1-up is available with a score of 10000000, there are a total of 5 stages and every stage has a mini boss and under certain conditions during the 5th stage you can get the true last boss.

Scoring During original mode the scoring mechanics are quite simple and to get good scoring you have to master surviving to gain the 1cc. Basically to get good scores you need to achieve NMNB (No miss No Bomb) The enemies drop gems and there are small and large diamond gems, small gems are worth 100 points, large ones 1000 which are dropped by airborne enemies. There are also gems for grounded enemies with small grounded gems worth 825 points and 2000points respectively.
The number of gems collected during the current life on the current stage with a bonus from no missing is added together as a score bonus at the end of each stage, and at the end of the final stage the number of lives remaining and bombs are multiplied resulting in the final score.

In the maniac and ultra mode, there is a counter called the parent counter and it increases when Reco is shooting enemies on the screen with her shot and decreases whenever she is not hitting an enemy, each enemy has their own counter that is similar to the parent counter and decreases if Reco is not shooting at it until it dies, and the higher the mulitiplier the more score you will recieve.You can gain an option powerup, a new counter called the child counter,the child counter will only increase if the options laser is hitting an enemy using her main shot, an advanced technique called counter banking allows you to use the C shot for example, if a player has 4 child counters with a vaulue of 500 each, everytime you counter bank, you will add 2000 to the parent counter causing your multiplier to skyrocket, mastering the technique and keeping track of your score and chaning will allow your parent counter to improve your score dramatically.

Overall Mushihimesama is an amazing game and in HD from its original 2004 arcade release, it looks amazing and worthy of being released on PC in 2015, its challenging with different modes for every skill level and you can spend months and years playing this game.

This has been a long time coming. Cave on STEAM. Time to dive right on in the Mushihimesama First mode I tried was arranged mode and I jumped right in for some good'ol fashioned score attack. What looks like a punishing barrage of bullets comes out to be very manageable as long as you breathe, don't panic, and pay attention. Nothing in this game is impossible outside of the most ludicrous difficulty. Don't take what I'm saying as the game being easy. It isn't. You'll be praying for some slowdowns to hit left and right in no time. It does help ease those in who are new to the genre and continues to step up the difficulty all the way until the end. The game does give beginners ample tools to help enjoy the game all the way until the end. It's up to the player to get their selves off the training wheels.

The game offers various difficulties, modes, ships (beetles) for you to heep on to your plate. Each mode offers different speeds, enemy patterns, bullet patterns, and all that other deliciousness to keep you busy for hours on end. Score Attack allows you to take on each mode with locked in game options to compete for highscores against fellow players. I'm already finding this to be my go to mode. For those looking for a more soothing experience you can go to novice mode and crank everything down all the way so you can enjoy artwork and exploding beetles while relaxing to some wonderful tunes that this game has to offer.

The presentation, art direction, and music for this game is fantastic. The game has beautiful menus with an array of backgrounds with music that will make you glad that you got this game early for that free soundtrack. The backgrounds and enemies make me want to crank the difficulty all the way down so I can take the time to admire the work CAVE put into designing and animating these bugs. On the other spectrum I want to crank the difficulty up so I can appreciate the beautiful bullet spreads that this game throws at you. If only I were good enough to make it to the end to enjoy them all.

Can't wait to get back into this game and sink some hours of my life into it. While I'm in no way close to being decent at shmups, this game makes me feel like I'm somewhat competent. The game does a great job of building player confidence and even when I died I rarely felt like it was because the game was unfair. It helps make me want to get better at memorizing enemy and bullet patterns so I can shoot for a 1CC.

reviewText:
This is a really good port of one of CAVES best shooters.  It's one of the more approachable bullet hell games they've made so it makes sense this would be the first one they bring over to get people interested over the arguably more difficult Dodonpachi Series.  Unlike other bullethell shooters, CAVE games don't rely on rote memorization to do well; They have a nice blend of freeform movement and tight bullet dodging which doesn't feel gimmicky or cheap.  If you're experienced in the genre or have good reflexes then even you can make it far on your first playthrough.

*The controls are as tight as they always were and every death will be your fault (no blaming th controls here :P)

*The game comes with 3 game modes (4 if you get the 1.5 DLC) each with 3 difficulty levels to control exactly how hard you want your experience to be.  You have Novice, Original, Arranged, and 1.5 (aka Matsuri).  Each has their own soundtrack which you can mix and match with other modes in the game in the options.  It's really customizable.

*The visuals are really crisp and good looking.  It's only in 720p, but it doesn't take away from the art direction and the cleaness of everything presented.  The menu is very slick and easy to navigate.  You won't be entering and exiting a lot of menues to switch modes or play with options for each game.

*The framerate is great at least for me.  It switches between 59-60 fps during gameplay but I've never visually noticed or felt it. The main menu where you select which mode you want to play is 30fps but once you choose a mode it changes to 60.  There is slowdown during the game but IT'S 100% INTENTIONAL.  Cave's games have what's known as earned" slowdown.  The game will LOOK like it's slowing down but if you look at your FPS counter it should still be +/-1 fps from 60 at all times during gameplay.  This is written 2 days after launch of the game but there have been framerate complaints from some people saying the game goes as low as 54fps for them.  I have a pretty basic non-gaming laptop and it runs fine for me.  I suspect it's some graphics card issue or they're running other programs in the background which might cause it to slow down.

All in all
date: if you are a veteran or a newbie trying to get into the genre then you can't go wrong with this quality title."

reviewText:
Since the start of the Shoot-em-up genre, CAVE has served as the undisputed king. Their games often feature amazing art direction, unique yet fair mechanics, and lots and lots and LOTS of bullets. CAVE games have always had the unique mix of qualities that appeal to both the hardcore twitch-heavy shooter fan, and the casual amateur player just getting his feet wet in the genre.

In short, I recommend this game to everyone. If you are a SHMUP fan, you don't need me, you probably bought this purely on instinct. If you aren't familiar with this type of game, or are just getting started, I recommend this as well, as it is relatively simple (by CAVE's standards), with a welcoming difficulty curve. Plus, it is just a beautiful game on many levels.

For the longest time, CAVE's games have been trapped in arcades, or limited console releases in Japan, only. The West has traditionally only seen one of these games released once in a while. With the modern growth of digital distribution, this is thankfully changing, and I expect (and hope) Steam will see more beautifully ported CAVE games such as this one.

The king has returned. All hail CAVE.

reviewText:
Cave showed up late to the party on Steam. We've already got an enormous assortment of shmups from Jamestown to the charming Gundemonium Collection, to the esoteric Senko no Ronde stylings of Suguri and Acceleration thereof. Eschatos brings the old school style mixed impeccably with modern design expertise (And subtlety, how rare in this genre.), Ikaruga brings Treasure's take, CrimzonClover takes us on a wild roller coaster ride on a V2 missile that explodes gloriously, Exceed 3rd puts us somewhere south of Touhou, north of Cave, and even Sine Mora shows you what terrible shmups are like.

So where does that leave Cave?

We all already know. Their flavor of shmup is balls to the wall, sensory overload. Loads of quick bullets in lovely patterns, undeniably lovely environments and bosses before and after they are charred with your bullets. This is twitch gaming at its purest.

The port is lovely, runs beautifully, with all manner of options, but I have to bow to a true enthusiast to give a definitive answer.

But the game itself? Classic Cave shooting action without some of the esoteric nonsense scoring of their later years.

No I don't know what Arrange Mode means either but you have at least two different flavors of campaign, along with several difficulty levels.

reviewText:
Mushihimesama is such a love/hate relationship for me.

The art and music are arguably the biggest selling points, still lush and elaborate as I remember them from my first experience with the game on the PlayStation 2, a notably barebones, mediocre, but at the time novel port.

This conversion of the Xbox 360 release is certainly more impressive in comparison despite the lack of proper resolution support, sufficiently equipped with enough alternate modes and difficulty settings to keep all but the pickiest bullet hell fans potentially busy for years to come.

Controls, arcade accuracy... no complaints; everything is how it should be.

So what's the problem, you might ask?

The challenge.

It's been nearly twenty years and CAVE still doesn't understand how to build challenge for anything that isn't running on a glorified quarter vacuum, their sole focus still centered around the high score. Outside of a pedantic, competition-driven few, no one cares about scores the moment a game steps away from the arcade and into their home collection; not a single one. It's a pointless endeavor that severely hampers Mushihimesama (et al.) at a core level.

In truth? There is no challenge here. Credits are unlimited; anything beyond a self-imposed 1cc rule offers nothing of real value or satisfaction and for a game rooted so heavily in a gameplay-centric genre, it more or less results in creative suicide.

Granted, this is not a problem exclusively endemic to Mushihimesama or the rest of CAVE's library; bullet hell as a niche has been guilty of it from the start, a major reason behind my strong preference for the classic array of shmups (Gradius, R-Type, anything by Compile). Still, I've tried to keep an open mind, revisiting the classic titles off and on over the years, but at the end of the day... I just don't understand the overall appeal beyond a very particular mindset. Probably never will, even if I should theoretically love the hell out of this game without question.

Final verdict: worth it if you're a part of the aforementioned mindset and/or a genre enthusiast. Everyone else? I wouldn't bother beyond potential novelty factor.

Well, this is a bullet hell -game very much by the book, and so, if you like or hate thing x you pretty much hate or like the entire genre. However, while I respect the genre, I cannot praise it blindly either...

First off, you can see every stage, every pattern, every mode etc. in less than 2 hours. Of course, mastering the stages is hardly the same as seeing them, but chances are you'll grow bored if you lack the perfectionism required.

While the visuals are high quality and the artwork follows a personal style too, the bosses are very much bug a, bug b and so on, I get that its in the title, but it feels like the transitions are noticeably few too, compared to say, Touhou...

Last but certainly not least, the archaic 'continue' -mechanic. Seriously, this is a feature from a time when arcade machines were designed to empty wallets, it has no place in PC games. But no, the game feels the need to actively pause the affair and make the player feel bad about themselves before lending them a chance to continue from the exact same spot, everything forgiven, as if (imaginary) money was indeed the magic bullet and solution to all problems. How hard would it be to implement stage resets upon continue, or better yet, boss stage resets? This way I could at least feel I've been given a genuine right to proceed after beating the boss, that I'd have overcome some sort of a wall on my own, rather than just admitting that I sucked.

reviewText: Let me tell you this is one addictive game.  Novice mode is super fun (press left on the main screen to access it) if you are not that good at shmups, and with 3 levels of difficulty for every mode, this game has tons of replay value.  You may want to read a scoring guide online (google will find one for you fast) to get the most out of this game, as there is no tutorial or instructions to speak of.  Try playing this with headphones...the soundtrack will blow you away though you may want to buy the soundtrack to listen to separately as it can be hard to focus on the music with so much happening on the screen!  My 2 gripes about this game are that the resolution options are not that great and that there is no explanation of the scoring, power-up items, or story in-game.  I would have at least liked some info to cover what a typical arcade pop might have, which would include what different icons mean and explanation of the shot types.  For the resolution issue, at least you can get the playfield the size you want it by adjusting the zoom, position, and zoom of the x and y axis separately, though it's hard to tell if you are playing on an arcade-accurate size ratio at that point.  Also, this must be done after choosing your mode, so you will need to set this 4 times (3 if you don't buy the DLC...but buy it).  Despite these problems I do not regret buying this game as it really shows why Cave is the master of this genre, I mean I was pretty much addicted after the first minute of playing and cannot wait to really get more into it!

reviewText:
An arcade style bullet hell shooter brought to you by Cave, the masters of the bullet hell genre, and a must-have for any danmaku fan out there.

Mushihimesama is a 2D horizontal SHMUP which lets you control princess Reco on her quest to stop the Koju from attacking a human village. You get to make your way through dense bullet patterns requiring both quick thinking and reflexes in 5 stages.

In terms of gameplay the game is simple like every SHMUP. You shoot enemies for points while avoiding enemy fire. The difficulty ranges from challenging to exceptionally tough. The enemies and bosses have fun and challenging bullet patterns.

The graphics are great for a 2D shooter. Sadly the game only supports up to 720p resolution but allows full screen stretching. The screen settings also support 90 degree flipping, for those that want the true arcade experience.

The soundtrack is great and fits the game's atmosphere. Boss themes got a bit of a dramatic touch in them, stage themes are adventurous or mysterious, depending on where you are.

Overall I love this game. It pretty much outclasses every other similar SHMUP available on Steam, and the only game coming close to it is Crimzon Clover: WORLD IGNITION. If you love getting punished by beautiful bullet patterns, then go buy it. If you're not familiar with the SHMUP genre, avoid the game (for now) as the insane difficulty will make you regret buying it.

Back in 2006 I paid many times more than what this game is selling for here to play the PS2 version released in Japan. I also had to mod my PS2 because region locking was a thing back then. Mushihimesama was probably a good choice for a first CAVE game port because of it's (relatively) simple mechanics and because it has a big boobs anime girl for all the weaboo types out there, but if that's not your thing then don't let it discourage you from buying it because right under the surface is a vicious game that will destroy you if you step up to the plate expecting to play soft toss. There's a reason it has a Novice mode that wasn't in the arcade releases.

Is it an arcade perfect port? I wouldn't know. Most of my experience with the game is with the PS2 port, which was generally considered less than perfect. On a technical level the porting job isn't a sloppy one, and from the looks of it the developer or responsive to user feedback so if you have a problem, speak up in the forums.

Few people outside the shmup community know it, but CAVE has more or less been considered the authority on shoot em' up games for the better part of 2 decades now. For those of us who have had exposure to the genre outside of the generally lackluster options available on Steam, this is a breath of fresh air.

reviewText:
An arcade style bullet hell shooter brought to you by Cave, the masters of the bullet hell genre, and a must-have for any danmaku fan out there.

Mushihimesama is a 2D horizontal SHMUP which lets you control princess Reco on her quest to stop the Koju from attacking a human village. You get to make your way through dense bullet patterns requiring both quick thinking and reflexes in 5 stages.

In terms of gameplay the game is simple like every SHMUP. You shoot enemies for points while avoiding enemy fire. The difficulty ranges from challenging to exceptionally tough. The enemies and bosses have fun and challenging bullet patterns.

The graphics are great for a 2D shooter. Sadly the game only supports up to 720p resolution but allows full screen stretching. The screen settings also support 90 degree flipping, for those that want the true arcade experience.

The soundtrack is great and fits the game's atmosphere. Boss themes got a bit of a dramatic touch in them, stage themes are adventurous or mysterious, depending on where you are.

Overall I love this game. It pretty much outclasses every other similar SHMUP available on Steam, and the only game coming close to it is Crimzon Clover: WORLD IGNITION. If you love getting punished by beautiful bullet patterns, then go buy it. If you're not familiar with the SHMUP genre, avoid the game (for now) as the insane difficulty will make you regret buying it.

reviewText:
I love this game :)

This is a bullet hell shoot'em up that, like most good games of its genre, possesses a lot of depth and challenge, especially when you start focusing on scoring. Replaying each stage and constantly learning new things and improving your survivability/score is a lot of fun!

Aside from Normal mode, this game provides a Novice mode (less/slower enemy bullets) and Arrange mode (different bullet patterns). If you own the DLC, you get access to the V1.5 mode (different enemy placements and bullet patterns). Normal and Novice modes provide 3 difficulty challenges each, with more complicated bullet patterns and scoring systems in higher difficulties.

I find the soundtrack awesome and quite catchy overall. Arrange and V1.5 modes have their own sets of remixed soundtracks, which you can also assign to other modes to keep the background music fresh.

The game came out with a few bugs but, as of this review, most of them, as far as my experience goes, have been resolved. I also find the more complicated scoring systems, present in higher difficulties or in certain modes, a bit convoluted at first, while the game doesn't do enough to explain them, which will require checking a guide or two.

If you like bullet hell shoot'em up games, this is is a very well-crafted and gorgeous one. If you don't like them, this might still be worth checking out, but will likely not change your mind. If you haven't tried any and you're curious about the genre, this is a good place to start, with its Novice mode serving as a nice starting point.
